EVACUATION OF RESIDENTS

The Incident Response Commander will notify the Fire Department who will determine if evacuation is necessary.  The Fire Department will make the necessary notifications in accordance with the previously agreed-upon sheltering plan.  Residences will be notified to shut windows and close any ventilation system and listen for further advisories.



NEIGHBORING FACILITIES

Neighboring facilities will be notified directly if they are affected or potentially affected.  These facilities have pre-established emergency response procedures that have been discussed with this facility¿s management.



CHLOREP ¿ OUTSIDE ASSISTANCE

In the event the ton container leak cannot be contained, our supplier, Harcor Chemicals will be contacted at  404-351-6000.  If assistance cannot be obtained, contact CHLOREP through CHEMTREC at 1-800-424-9300.  Describe the problem as well as the required help needed.  The Production Manager, David Whitson, will make these contacts.



PLAN REVIEW/REVISION DATE

This site-specific Emergency Response Plan was originally developed June 21, 1999 and was revised on June 1, 2003.  This current revision is dated June 21, 2004.  It is the policy of the Henry County Board of Commissioners to review this plan, as well as OSHA regulations t

hat might impact it, on an annual basis.  The plan will be audited annually to evaluate the efficacy of the plan and a critique will be incorporated following any emergency response action taken.  The plan will be updated to reflect any procedural modifications or changes in regulations that affect the Emergency Response Plan.  The Division Manager is responsible for reviewing and revising this plan.

Training of personnel with respect to this plan will be an ongoing process until such time as the staff have all received the required education from internal and outside agencies.

All review and revision records will include, at a minimum, the name and signature of the reviewer, the date of review, and a record of all revisions that were made.  (Review/Revision Form is included in Appendix 12.)



TRAINING

Training for all emergency responders, as required by the Emergency Response Regulation, 29 CFR 1910.120(q) will be certified for each employee.  Annual refresher training, also required by the OSHA regulations will be assured for each emergency responder.

First Responders at the Awareness Level must have sufficient training or have had sufficient experience to objectively demonstrate competency in the following areas:

·	Understanding of the hazards associated with chlorine gas.
·	Understanding of the potential outcomes associated with an emergency created when hazardous substances are present.
·	Ability to recognize the presence of hazardous substances in an emergency.
·	Ability to identify the hazardous substances.
·	Understanding of the role of the First Responder Awareness Level individual in the employer¿s emergency response plan including site security and control and the U.S. Department of Transportation¿s Emergency Response Guidebook.
·	Ability to realize the need for additional resources, and to make appropriate notifications to the communication center.

CHANGING ONE-TON CHLORINE CYLINDERS

1.	Make sure the cylinders are empty¿
a.	zero on the pressure gauge at the chlorinators
b.	zero on the weight scales
c.	turn on the exhaust fan

2.	Two-person minimum will be used to change out cylinders.  One will stand by the doorway with radio communication, ready to put on the full breathing apparatus if necessary, while the other person is changing out the cylinders.  The person changing the cylinders will carry an escape respirator on them, to be used to exit the room in case of a leak.

3.	Close the valves on both empty cylinders and pigtail/yoke assemblies.  Close both valves on the manifold to insure no air or moisture is drawn back into the pigtail in leading to the cylinders.  (NOTE:  NEVER STRIKE VALVE WRENCHES OR USE CHEATER BARS.)

4.	Remove the yoke assemblies by adjusting the bolt on the yoke assemblies.  Once the yoke assemblies are removed, screw the valve caps onto the cylinder valves.

5.	Using the hoist, move empty cylinders to the cradle at the farthest point from the scales, turning the valve end of the cylinders toward the west end of the room.  Replace the valve covers on the cylinders and mark the cylinder with an empty tag.  When moving full cylinders, make sure the valves are lined up from top to bottom when placing the cylinders on the scales.  Remove the valve cover.  Using the chlorine valve wrench, make sure the valves are closed before unscrewing the valve caps.  Test for leaks with AMMONIA SOLUTION.

6.	Remove valve caps for yoke assembly connection.  Befor

e connecting yoke assembly, be sure to replace old lead washer with a new lead washer.  Connect the yoke assembly and tighten it down.  Do not over tighten as this could cause a leak at the assembly.  Using a chlorine valve wrench, open the valve a ¼ turn and close it back.  (IF VALVE WILL NOT OPEN, ROTATE CYLINDER AND USE THE OTHER VALVE.)  Test for leaks using the AMMONIA SOLUTION.  If there are no leaks, open all the valves one full turn and test for leaks under normal line pressure.

7.	Set the weight on the scales and turn off exhaust fan.

DRILLS AND EXERCISES

Actual drills and exercises for mock release responses will be conducted on an annual basis.  Logs will be maintained to document personnel training/exercise sessions.  All emergency equipment and personal protective equipment will be inspected and maintained in good working order by the Incident Response Commander/Site Safety Officer.  The monthly (and post-use) inspection information will be maintained in a log along with any repairs that were made.

Facility evacuation drills will be performed annually.


 
SCENARIO A ¿ A RELEASE CAN BE CONTAINED BY ONSITE PERSONNEL

A RELEASE OF CHLORINE HAS OCCURRED

1.	Alarm sounds.

2.	Notify Incident Response Commander (¿IC¿)/Site Safety Officer, David Whitson.

3.	Summon Plant Operators.

4.	Secure the area.

5.	Gather all employees/visitors in front of the Maintenance Building, to await further instruction and head count.  All employees are accounted for.

6.	Plant Operators (2) dress out in Level B with SCBA.

7.	IC sets up work zones and decontamination sequence and determines the need for standby rescue personnel.

8.	Plant Operators assess the release.

9.	Plant Operators shut off a valve thereby stopping the release.

10.	Plant Operators go through decontamination.

11.	IC declares all clear for re-occupa

ncy.

12.	IC or designated MANAGER makes internal and external notifications¿the State Emergency Response Commission and Henry County Emergency Management.  If more than 10 pounds of chlorine has been released, then notify the National Response Center.

13.	IC prepares follow-up reports to agencies and writes up a critique of the incident.
 
 SCENARIO B ¿ A RELEASE IS OF SUFFICIENT SIZE OR HAS THE POTENTIAL TO MIGRATE OFF THE GROUNDS AND REQUIRES OFF-SITE ASSISTANCE

A RELEASE OF CHLORINE HAS OCCURRED

1.	Alarm sounds.

2.	Notify Incident Response Commander (¿IC¿)/Site Safety Officer, David Whitson.

3.	Summon Plan Operators.

4.	Secure the area.

5.	Gather all employees/visitors in front of the Maintenance Building, to await further instruction and head count.  All employees are accounted for.

6.	Plant Operators (2) dress out in Level B with SCBA.

7.	IC sets up work zones and decontamination sequence and determines the need for standby rescue personnel.

8.	Plant Operators assess the release.

9.	IC and Plant Operators determine the response requires outside assistance.

10.	IC or designated MANAGER calls the Fire Department and Henry County Police and notifies Henry Medical Center.

11.	IC or designated MANAGER notifies National Response Center (if more than 10 pounds of chlorine has been released), the State Emergency Response Commission and Henry County Emergency Management.

12.	Evacuate employees/visitors to Lester Mill Road gates and South to the Griffin/Locust Grove Road and account for all persons.

13.	Fire Department evacuates residents, if necessary.

14.	IC or designated MANAGER notifies neighboring facilities (N/A) and General Manager.

15.	Plant Operators stop the release.***

16.	Plant Operators decontaminate.

17.	IC declares all clear for re-occupancy.

18.	IC prepares follow-up report for agencies and writes critique of the incident.

Full-body chemical-resistant suits, chemical-resistant inner and outer gloves and outer chemical-resistant boot covers are required to protect employees from chlorine gas.  The pant leg/boot interface and the glove/sleeve interface must be taped securely.  The Incident Response Commander/Site Safety Officer will be responsible for implementing the PPE program.

Personnel will follow the manufacturer¿s procedures for donning and doffing PPE.

The PPE program addresses the following: use and limitations of the equipment; work mission duration; PPE maintenance and storage; decontamination or disposal; training; PPE proper fitting; inspection procedures prior to, during and after use; evaluation of the effectiveness of the program; and limitations during temperature extremes, heat stress and other appropriate medical considerations.

MEDICAL SURVEILLANCE REQUIREMENTS
Emergency Response

29 CFR 1910.120(f)


All members of a HAZMAT response team (Hazardous Materials Technicians) as well as standby rescue personnel are required to receive a baseline physical examination and be provided with medical surveillance as required by paragraph (f) of the regulation.

Additionally, any emergency response employees who exhibit signs or symptoms that may have resulted from an exposure to hazardous substances during the course of an emergency incident either immediately or subsequently, will be provided with medical consultation immediately as required in paragraph (f)(3)(ii) of this regulation.

Medical examinations and consultations will be made available prior to assignment to the response team before such duties are allowed to be executed (initial medical exam) and at least once every 12 months unless the attending physician believes a longer interval (not to exceed every two years) is appropriate. DECONTAMINATION EQUIPMENT AND SEQUENCE

CFR 1910.120(k)


The Incident Response Commander/Site Safety Officer is responsible for assuring that the decontamination sequence is established in the Contamination Reduction Corridor and that all workers in the Exclusion Zone (response work area) go through decontamination before entering the clean or Support Zone.  All personnel going through decontamination will continue to wear respiratory protection until full decontamination of suits, boots and gloves has been achieved.  This is to prevent an exposure hazard to the operator from off-gassing of any residual chlorine on the PPE.

Decontamination will be performed using a mild detergent, such as dishwashing liquid detergent, and water.  All decontamination liquids will be collected for proper disposal.  Standby rescue personnel, properly equipped with PPE, can assist in d

Sewerage Authority.  Medical examinations and consultations will be provided additionally if the examining physician determines that follow-up exams or consultations are medically necessary.

The content of the medical examinations and consultations will include a medical and work history with special emphasis on symptoms related to exposure to chlorine gas, as well as to fitness for duty including the ability to wear a Level B suit and SCBA under temperature extremes that may be expected at the work site.

Further, the content of the exams will reflect the guidelines in the OSHA Guidance Manual for Hazardous Waste Site Activities.  (Copy included in this Appendix.)

All medical examinations and procedures will be performed by or under the supervision of a licensed physician, preferably one knowledgeable in occupational medicine, and will be provided at no cost, without loss of pay, and at a reasonable time and place.

Henry County Water & Sewerage Authority will provide the examining physician with the following information:

·	A copy of the OSHA Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response Regulation, 29 CFR 1910.120 and its Appendices.
·	A description of the employee¿s duties as they relate to the employee¿s potential exposure during an emergency response.
·	Information that the exposure level will be unknown.
·	A description of any personal protective equipment used or to be used.
·	Information from previous medical examinations of the employee that is not available readily to the examining physician.
·	Information required by the OSHA Respiratory Protection Regulation, 29 CFR 1910.134.

Henry County Water & Sewerage Authority will obtain and furnish the employee with a copy of a written opinion from the examining physician containing the following information:

·	The physician¿s opinion as to whether the employee has any detected medical conditions that would place the employee at increased risk of material impairment of the employee¿s health from work in

econtamination of workers.

Emergency Decontamination:  In an emergency, the primary concern is to prevent the loss of life or severe injury to Site personnel.  If immediate medical treatment is required to save a life, decontamination should be delayed until the victim is stabilized.  If decontamination can be performed without interfering with essential life-saving techniques or first aid, decontamination should be performed.  If an emergency due to a heat-related illness develops, protective clothing should be removed from the victim as soon as possible to reduce heat stress.

Provisions also have been made for protecting medical personnel and disposing of contaminated clothing and equipment.  Henry County EMTs have been trained to perform decontamination in the field.  They will know the hazard that they are dealing with before coming to the Site and will come adequately equipped.

POST INCIDENT INVESTIGATION


The Site Incident Response Commander, David Whitson, will perform post incident investigation and develop a report of findings.  The investigation is performed to determine the cause of the accident and may involve coordination with federal, state and local officials.

Information on the cause, amount released, resources impacted, injuries, response actions, etc. will be included in the certified report and a copy of the report will be maintained on file as well as added to the Appendix.

The post accident investigation and documentation is important in all cases, but especially so when the accident has resulted in personal injury, onsite property damage, or damage to the surrounding environment.  Documentation may be used to help avert recurrences, as evidence in future legal action, for assessment of liability by insurance companies, and for review by government agencies.  Methods of documentation can include a written transcript taken from tape recordings made during the emergency or a bound field book (not a loose-leaf book) with notes.  The document must be:

·	Accurate:  All information must be recorded objectively.

·	Authentic:  A chain-of-custody procedure should be used.  Each person making an entry must date and sign the document.  Keep the number of documentors to a minimum to avoid confusion and because they may have to give testimony in court.  Nothing should be erased.  If details change or revisions are needed, the person making the notation should mark a horizontal line through the old material and initial the change.

·	Complete:  At a minimum, the following should be included:

Update of the verbal information given previously.
Chronological history of the incident.
Facts about the incident and when they be

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Henry County Water and Sewerage Authority has owned and operated water and wastewater treatment facilities within Henry County, Georgia for thirty years.  During this time the Authority has utilized chlorine gas for the disinfection of the treated water and wastewater.  To date there has been no reportable incident, over the ten-pound release, that has affected the health and safety of the employees or the communities where these facilities operate.

With the safety and welfare of its employees and the community at the forefront,  the Henry County Water and Sewerage Authority has developed a Risk Management Plan.  This plan has been submitted to all local emergency services to provide a comprehensive response to all possible scenarios related to the release of chlorine gas.  This plan to assure an orderly and complete response to issues that could arise in the utilization of chlorine gas



SCOPE AND PURPOSE OF THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

It is the policy of the Henry County Water & Sewerage Authority, Towaliga River Water Treatment Facility, to protect all workers and the community around this facility against known and anticipated hazards during the course of work operations as well as any emergencies arising at the plant.  Additionally, a site specific Emergency Response Plan has been  developed to ensure that all coordination with outside organizations including the National Response Center, the Georgia State Emergency Response Commission, Henry County Emergency Response Management, law enforcement, the Henry County Fire Department, Henry Medical Center, and emergency medical technicians is assured.

With the careful enforcement and execution of this Emergency Response Plan, in the event of an emergency release of hazardous gases at this facility, the harm to workers, the public and the environment will be minimized.  The Emergency Response Plan will address community planning and communication, how this facility will interact with local

officials to assist with public evacuation, and specify safe distances of refuge and rally points.  

The scope of this plan includes a chlorine gas release which can be contained within the facility and controllable by plant personnel and equipment, and a chlorine release affecting or with the potential to affect off-site areas around the facility, requiring outside assistance from the Henry County Fire Department.


TYPES OF EMERGENCIES

A Release of Chlorine Gas

There are several points at which a ¿leak¿ could occur in the piping system, allowing a small amount or a large amount of chlorine gas to be released into the environment:

1.	The first point in the chlorination line is at the one-ton cylinders themselves.  The valve could fail or rupture, resulting in the release of the contents of the cylinder.  If this occurs, a major release could occur and this is the worst case scenario for an emergency response at the Site. The gas could not be stopped by shutting off a valve, and the use of a B Kit for repairs would be in order.

2.	The schedule 120# steel feed lines (approximately 15¿ of line) could develop a pin-hole leak, crack or break.  This could result in the release of a significant amount of chlorine gas very quickly depending on the extent of the break in the line.  This, too would constitute a worst case scenario for emergency response.  However, a leak here could be stopped by shutting off a valve.

3.	Inside the control room there are a few potential break/leak points for the release of chlorine gas, including approximately 10 feet of pipe runs with numerous valves, elbows, tees and joints where leaks could develop.  The piping lines that carry the chlorine into the eductors could develop a leak or rupture, releasing chlorine gas into the air.  This could constitute a worst case scenario for emergency response.

4.	Normal operations could result in an emergency response.  Hooking up the new chlorine cylinders to the manifold could result in a release

of chlorine gas.

5.	The valve at the diffuser is another potential point for a leak to develop, resulting in emergency response.

6.	Although not likely, the cylinders themselves could develop a leak or rupture.

There are continuous monitoring sensors for chlorine gas located in the cylinder storage area.  A release in this area could be quickly detected by this sensor and an alarm would sound that can be heard throughout the facility, grounds and office building, as well as the visual alarm indicators.


Loss of Utilities

At this facility, the loss of utilities including electricity will not increase the potential for a release of chlorine gas.  


Threatening Weather
In the event of dangerous weather such as a hurricane or tornado, all plant personnel and onsite visitors will gather at the designated rally point.


Bomb Threat Procedures

Most bomb threats are telephoned in and are usually hoaxes.  It is still important to take all bomb threats seriously.  The person answering the phone must get as much information as possible from the caller.  The bomb threat work sheet is contained in Appendix 11 of this document.

Upon completion of the bomb threat work sheet, the person taking the call will immediately notify the ranking supervisor.  The ranking supervisor will make the determination whether the call is a credible threat or if it is uncertain as to whether it is a credible threat.  If it is credible, the facility will be evacuated.  The bomb squad will be called, and if time permits, a search of the facility will be undertaken in an attempt to find the bomb.  If it is uncertain as to whether the threat is credible, the ranking supervisor will inform employees of the threat and make a decision as to what further action needs to be taken.

Bomb threats received through the mail must also be taken seriously.  Employees should use the precautionary procedures posted on the main bulletin board prior to opening all mail.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROCEDURES

Discovery

A release of chlorine gas at the cylinders themselves or in the chlorine storage room will result in the sounding of the sensor alarm siren that can be heard throughout the facility and grounds, as well as visual alarm indicators.  (See example procedures in Appendix 1, Scenarios A-D.)

An employee discovering a release of chlorine gas which has not resulted in activation of the automatic alarm system is to immediately sound the alarm and then notify all other personnel and visitors to the Site that a release has occurred.

The Incident Response Commander, David Whitson, must be notified immediately, and plant operators (Hazardous Materials Technicians) summoned.

Building Evacuation and Initial Rally Point

All site personnel and visitors will immediately gather at the rally point¿in front of the Maintenance Building¿and await further direction from the Incident Response Commander.


Sizing Up the Situation

Plant employees trained as First Responder Operations Level will secure the area to make sure no unauthorized persons enter.

Two Hazardous Materials Technicians (Plant Operators) suited up in Level B suits and full face-piece SCBAs will approach the area to assess the nature and extent of the release and determine the necessary response action.

If turning a valve will stop the release, that action will be taken.  If more extensive action needs to be taken, the Hazardous Materials Technicians in coordination with the Incident Response Commander will determine what needs to be done and the technicians will perform the repairs.

If deemed necessary by the Incident Response Commander, who is also the Site Safety Officer, one or two standby rescue personnel will partially suit-up and be prepared to perform rescue if need

ed.

If the repairs will take time to complete or the release is deemed to be of significant size so there is a possibility of off-site migration, the Fire Department will be called.

A ranking supervisor of the Incident Response Commander will immediately call the Henry County Fire Department (911), and the Henry County Police Department.  The Incident Response Commander will meet or will delegate an available person to meet at the front gate and escort any outside responders notified to assist in the response.  If the front gate is not accessible, the responders will be met at the public road upwind of the release.

The Incident Response Commander/Site Safety Officer will establish work zones, as needed, to include the Exclusion Zone, the Contamination Reduction Zone and Decontamination Sequence and the Support Zone.

The Incident Response Commander will preliminarily assess the areas/resources threatened, but will turn over authority to the Fire Chief as soon as he arrives to take action.  The Fire Chief will initiate and execute any public evacuation deemed necessary.


Plant Evacuation

In the event of the need to evacuate the Site to an off-site location, the designated employees, the Superintendent of Maintenance, trained to escort the evacuation to the rally point and account for all employees, will direct the evacuation.

When winds are out of the West, the designated rally point is the Maintenance Building.  The Incident Response Commander will designate an alternate rally point in the event the wind is from another direction.  The rally point will be located, at a minimum, 1200 feet away, upwind of the incident. Windsocks will be placed at the Site to indicate the wind direction.  All personnel evacuating the Site will be instructed to remain crosswind or upwind of the gas at all times.

The Site¿s normal operational schedule will be used to account for all employees at the rally point.  Any unaccounted-for personnel will be reported immediately to the In

cident Response Commander who will initiate search and rescue operations.

Based on the final decision by the Fire Department, it may be necessary to protect persons downwind during the day:  >0.1 miles for a small release of chlorine and 1.0 miles for a large release.  A nighttime release of chlorine gas might necessitate protecting persons downwind up to 0.1 miles, and 2.3 miles for a large release of chlorine gas.  (See the radius map in Appendix 2.)

The Incident Response Commander or a designated employee will call Henry Medical Center Emergency Room at (770) 389-2260 and inform them that a release has occurred.  In the event anyone is overcome by the gas, the EMTs will be called at that same number.

Emergency Numbers (Appendix 1) are posted by telephones and on bulletin boards.  Evacuation routes (Appendix 2) are posted in work areas and in the main offices.

The use of example scenarios included in Appendix 1 will be utilized to assure that all necessary actions for emergency response have been taken.



TERMINATION AND FOLLOW-UP ACTIONS

Post-incident procedures will be dictated by the extent of the release and subsequent emergency response.  All clear for re-occupancy will be determined by the Senior Official present at the Site upon conclusion of the response.  The Incident Response Commander will declare all-clear before personnel are allowed to return to the Site.


Decontamination

Immediately upon completing repairs and exiting the Exclusion Zone, all Hazardous Materials Technicians will decontaminate thoroughly using a mild detergent and water, and continue to wear respiratory protection until inside the Support Zone.  (See Appendix 6.)

1.	The National Response Center
2.	The Henry County Emergency Response Management
3.	The State Emergency

Response Commission (The State wants to be notified of any release, regardless of the amount.)

Written follow-up is required to be provided to these agencies as soon as practicable after the incident occurs.
